emphasis.docTitle:
Thriving in dry conditions: on the Neotropical spider genus
Galapa
( Araneae : Pholcidae )

subSection.paragraph: BERNHARD A. HUBER 1,4* , GUANLIANG MENG 1,5 , JIMMY CABRA GARCÍA 2 & LEONARDO S. CARVALHO 3

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig, LIB, Bonn, Germany .
Departamento de Biología, Universidad del Valle, Cali, Colombia .

subSection.paragraph: � jimmy.cabra@correounivalle.edu.co; https://orcid.org/0000-0001-9263-4390

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Campus Amílcar Ferreira Sobral, Universidade Federal do Piauí , Floriano, Piauí , Brazil .

subSection.paragraph: � carvalho@ufpi.edu.br; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4700-5610

4
�
b.huber@leibniz-lib.de ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-7566-5424

5
�
G. Meng@leibniz-lib.de ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-6488-1527

The genus
Galapa Huber, 2000
includes tiny spiders (body length < 1.5 mm ) restricted to semi-arid habitats. It has long been thought to be endemic to the Galapagos Islands until
G. spiniphila Huber, 2020
was described from the Venezuelan Paraguaná Peninsula. Here, we support this generic assignment with molecular (CO1) data and describe two new species from Colombia (
G. gabito Huber
sp. n. ) and Costa Rica (
G. murphyi Huber
sp. n. ), showing that the genus is actually widely distributed. Distribution modelling identifies several high suitability areas for
Galapa
, all of which are poorly sampled with respect to Pholcidae (ranging from Nicaragua to northern Peru and Guiana ). Our results suggest a strong sampling bias against spiders restricted to dry tropical regions and habitats.

Key words : CO 1 barcodes , distribution modelling , new species ,
Ninetinae
, sampling bias , taxonomy

Pholcidae , or daddy long-legs spiders, are among the most species rich spider families ( World Spider Catalog 2023 ), but most of this diversity is within only two subfamilies that have speciated extensively in humid tropical forests. In the New World, this is mainly Modisiminae (currently 530 described species), while in the Old World it is Pholcinae (1077 species). Representatives of these two subfamilies can be found in a wide range of forest microhabitats, which probably explains their rich diversity also in terms of body size, shape, coloration, leg length, and ecology (
Eberle et al. 2018
). Even congeneric species in Modisiminae and Pholcinae are sometimes superficially extremely different from each other (e.g., in
Mesabolivar González-Sponga
and
Belisana Thorell
; Huber 2005 , 2018).

The other three currently known subfamilies, Arteminae, Ninetinae , and Smeringopinae , are largely restricted to dryer habitats and appear to be much less diverse, both in terms of species numbers (together currently 330 species) and with respect to morphology and ecology. The limited number of different microhabitats in dry environments means that congeneric species necessarily tend to occupy similar microhabitats. As a result, they are often indistinguishable in the field and can only be separated by details of genital morphology or molecular data (e.g.,
Aharon et al. 2017
; Huber 2022; Nolasco & Valdez-Mondragón 2022 ).

Recent focused collecting in dry regions suggests that we have a biased view regarding Ninetinae species diversity. For example, a recent campaign in semi-arid Brazilian biomes has resulted in over 1500 adult specimens representing approximately 30 species of Ninetinae , most of them new to science (B.A. Huber & L.S. Carvalho, unpubl. data). Recent and ongoing revisions resulted and will result in substantial increases in the numbers of known species. For example, a recent revision of the southern South American genus
Nerudia Huber, 2000
increased the species number from one to ten (
Huber et al. 2023a
); an ongoing revision of the South American genus
Ibotyporanga Mello-Leitão, 1944
will increase the species number from five to 24 (B.A. Huber et al. , unpubl. data).

Another major gap of knowledge in Ninetinae concerns distribution. This is well exemplified by the genus that is the focus of the present contribution.
Galapa Huber
was originally established for two species from Galapagos ( Huber 2000 ), and for two decades the genus was considered endemic to the archipelago. In 2020, a newly discovered Venezuelan spider was assigned to
Galapa
, suggesting a much wider distribution, but the assignment was based on specific similarities rather than on a formal analysis ( Huber & Villarreal 2020 ). Here, we provide the first such analysis, supporting the systematic placement of the Venezuelan species. In addition, we describe two new species and provide new records for
Galapa
from Colombia and Costa Rica , allowing us to model the potential distribution of the genus. Finally, we provide the first extensive SEM data of four species, complementing recent comparable data on related genera (
Huber et al. 2023a
, b, c) as a basis for an upcoming cladistic morphological analysis of Ninetinae .

This study is based on the examination of more than 200 adult specimens of
Galapa
deposited in the following institutions: Invertebrates Collection of the Charles Darwin Research Station, Galápagos , Ecuador (ICCDRS); Muséum d'Histoire Naturelle, Genève , Switzerland ( MHNG ); Manchester Museum, University of Manchester , Great Britain ( MMUE ); Museo de Entomología de la Universidad del Valle, Cali, Colombia (MUSENUV); and Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum Alexander Koenig, Bonn, Germany ( ZFMK ). Further material deposited in Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique , Brussels (IRSNB) and California Academy of Sciences, San Francisco (CAS) was examined by the first author in 1999 but not re-examined for the present study. ZFMK material with Ar codes is kept in 80% ethanol at room temperature; material with other codes is in pure ethanol at -18°C.

Taxonomic descriptions follow the style of recent publications on Ninetinae (e.g.,
Huber et al. 2023a
, b; based on Huber 2000 ). Measurements were done on a dissecting microscope with an ocular grid and are in mm unless otherwise noted; eye measurements are +/- 5 µm. Photos were made with a Nikon Coolpix 995 digital camera (2048 x 1536 pixels) mounted on a Nikon SMZ 18 stereo microscope or a Leitz Dialux 20 compound microscope. CombineZP (https://combinezp.software.informer.com/) was used for stacking photos. Drawings are partly based on photos that were traced on a light table and later improved under a dissecting microscope, or they were directly drawn with a Leitz Dialux 20 compound microscope using a drawing tube. Cleared epigyna were stained with chlorazol black. The number of decimals in coordinates gives a rough indication of the accuracy of the locality data: four decimals means that the collecting site is within about 10 m of the indicated spot; three decimals: within ~ 100 m ; two decimals: within ~ 1 km . The distribution map was generated with ArcMap 10.0. For SEM photos, specimens were dried in hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) ( Brown 1993 ) and photographed with a Zeiss Sigma 300 VP scanning electron microscope. Abbreviations used in figures only are explained in the figure legends. Abbreviations used in the text: ALE = anterior lateral eye(s); ALS = anterior lateral spinneret(s); AME = anterior median eye(s); a.s.l. = above sea level; L/d = length/diameter; PME = posterior median eye(s); PMS = posterior median spinneret(s).

subSection.paragraph:
Taxonomic sampling. We newly generated CO1 barcodes of 13 specimens of representatives of
Galapa
( Table 1 ). To this we added CO1 barcodes of five outgroup species belonging to closely related genera (according to upcoming analyses of UCE data; G. Meng, L Podsiadlowski, B.A Huber, unpubl. data): four from
Eberle et al. (2018)
: S347
Guaranita yaculica Huber
; JA83
Pemona sapo Huber
; S328
Kambiwa neotropica (Kraus)
; S358
Kambiwa sp.
“MACN273”; and one from
Huber et al. (2023c)
: N037
Guaranita goloboffi Huber. For
rooting the tree, we used two more distantly related Ninetinae taken from
Eberle et al. (2018)
: JA123
Ibotyporanga naideae Mello-Leitão
and S443
Ibotyporanga sp.
“Br16-149”. The complete set of analyzed taxa is listed in Supplementary File, Table S1 .

DNA extraction, amplification, and sequencing. Two to four legs of specimens stored in non-denatured pure ethanol (~99%) at -20° C were used for DNA extraction. Extracted genomic DNA is deposited at and available from the LIB Biobank, Museum Koenig, Bonn. DNA was extracted using the BioSprint® 96 DNA Blood Kit (Qiagen). The CO1 primers used were LCO1490-JJ and HCO2198-JJ (
Astrin et al. 2016
; primer versions JJ2 served as backup). The 20 µl reaction volume consisted of 4.4 µl H 2 O, 2 µl DNA template, 2 µl Q-Solution, 10 µl Qiagen Multiplex-Mix, 0.8 µl forward primer and 0.8 µl reverse primer. The PCR program ran two cycle sets, as a combination of a ‘touchdown’ and a ‘step-up’ routine: (1) 15 min hot start Taq activation at 95°C; (2) first cycle set (15 repeats): 35 s denaturation at 94°C, 90 s annealing at 55°C (−1°C per cycle) and 90 s extension at 72°C; (3) second cycle set (25 repeats): 35 s denaturation at 94°C, 90 s annealing at 40°C, and 90 s extension at 72°C; (4) final elongation 10 min at 72°C. PCR products were sent for bidirectional Sanger sequencing to BGI ( Hong Kong , China ).

We hypothesized that the apparently disjunct distribution of the genus
Galapa
is explained by sampling bias. We further expected that representatives of
Galapa
occur at similar environmental conditions throughout the range of the genus. We tested these hypotheses using two approaches. First, we did a distribution modelling for the genus and compared areas with high suitability with known records of pholcids in general. Second, we compared altitude and aridity among
Galapa
populations and other pholcids from the same regions.

We ran a species distribution modelling (SDM) using all
Galapa species
records combined. This approach disregards individual species environmental thresholds, but it serves as a qualitative exploratory analysis to assess the sampling bias for the genus by modelling areas with high suitability (for examples of similar studies with other spiders, see
Magalhães et al. 2016
;
Huber et al. 2023a
). The SDM was carried out using the 19 climatic variables available in WorldClim 2.1 ( Fick & Hijmans 2017 ), mean tree density (
Crowther et al. 2015
), mean canopy height (
Simard et al. 2011
), and global aridity index (
Zomer et al. 2022
), all at 1 km 2 scale. All layers were clipped using ArcMap 10.8 (Environmental Systems Research Institute, Redlands, CA) at about 500 and 700 km from the most northern and southern records of
Galapa
, respectively. The spatial autocorrelation between the predictor layers was removed by performing a principal component analysis (PCA) using the corresponding function in the BioDinamica package in Dinamica EGO (
Oliveira et al. 2019
). In the SDM, we used all axes that explained at least the variation expected by chance (i.e., for 22 axes, each axis that explained at least 4.54% of the proportional variance). The modelling was performed using a raw output, with a maximum of 1000 interactions, a random test percentage of 25%, removing duplicates from the same gridcell, random seed, and 15 bootstrap replicates. This is the same set of parameters as in
Huber et al. (2023a)
, following the recommendations by
Merow et al. (2013)
. The map representing the median of the replicates was adjusted with a 2.5 standard deviations stretched symbology in ArcMap 10.8. The results are discussed based on the known distribution of pholcids from northern South America and Central America, gathered from a database combining all published and unpublished records known to us (B.A. Huber & L.S. Carvalho, unpubl. data). Neotropical regionalization followed Morrone (2017) and
Olson et al. (2001)
.

The altitudes and the aridity indices of localities where
Galapa
representatives have been recorded were compared using generalized linear models. Due to overdispersion issues, we used a quasipoisson distribution of errors. Post hoc contrast analyses were performed using the ‘coms’ function in the R package ‘RT4Bio’ (
Reis-Junior et al. 2015
). Altitude was chosen due to the results of the distribution modelling, suggesting that
Galapa
representatives occupy low altitude areas. For this analysis, we used the raw altitude data gathered upon collecting each specimen (most records). Alternatively, for ca. 2% of the records, we extracted altitude data based on the geographic coordinates using the altitude raster from WorldClim 2.1 ( Fick & Hijmans 2017 ). The aridity index was chosen as it was the most important variable for the first axis of a PCA using Pholcidae occurrences based on records from the study area.

Figure 1 shows a neighbor-joining tree of all available CO1 sequences of
Galapa
. For the complete tree, including outgroups, see Supplementary File, Fig. S1 . Genetic distances among the sequenced specimens of
Galapa
are shown in Table 2 . For the complete table showing all distances among all specimens analyzed in this study, see Supplementary File, Table S2 . The average genetic (K2P) distance between
Galapa
specimens and Ninetinae outgroups was 21.7% (18.3–24.7%, N=91). Among species of
Galapa
, the average distance was slightly lower, at 17.9% (13.5–23.4%; N=63). Within the species of
Galapa
, the average distance was 6.2% (0.5–10.1%; N=15). This wide range is due to the fact that several specimens that show slight morphological variation are included and assigned tentatively to one of the nominal species. The average distance between these problematic specimens and nominal conspecifics to which they were assigned was 9.2% (8.2–10.2%; N=8). Excluding these problematic specimens and counting only unproblematic conspecifics, the average distance was 2.7% (0.5–4.8%; N=7).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis . Tiny (body length ~1.0– 1.5 mm ), short-legged, eight-eyed pholcids with globular abdomen ( Fig. 2 ). Males are easily distinguished from all other known Ninetinae by modified cheliceral fangs and by absence of frontal modifications on base segment of chelicera ( Figs 3 , 8A , 13C ). Similar chelicerae occur only in the distantly related Modisiminae genus
Chibchea Huber. Further
distinguished by dorsal process on procursus ( Figs 7B , 14B , 21B ; similar only in the southern South American genus
Guaranita Huber
), and by retrolateral distal process on procursus ( Figs 7B , 14B , 21B ). Females are externally very similar to other small New World Ninetinae such as
Guaranita
,
Tolteca Huber
, and
Kambiwa Huber
(in terms of body size, body shape, coloration, leg length, and simple epigynal plate); distinguished from these by internal genitalia: large membranous structure ( Figs 11D , 16F , 24G ) rather than pair of receptacles (
Tolteca
) or median receptacle (
Guaranita
,
Kambiwa
).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description (amendments; see Huber 2000 ).
Male

MEASUREMENTS.Total body length~1.0–1.5.Male carapace width0.38–0.60.Distance PME-PME35–45µm; diameter PME30–45 µm;distance PME-ALE 15µm;distanceAME-AME 10–15 µm;diameterAME 15–30µm.Tibia 1 length 0.41–0.74.Tibia 1 L/d:9–10.Leg formula 4123. Diameters of leg femora 0.075–0.10, of leg tibiae:0.05–0.06.
COLOUR (in ethanol). Prosoma and legs pale ochre-yellow, carapace without pattern, legs without darker rings; abdomen ochre-grey, monochromous or with indistinct internal marks.

BODY. Ocular area not raised. Carapace without thoracic groove ( Figs 6A , 20A , 27A ). Clypeus either not more protruding than in females ( Galapagos species) or slightly more protruding than in females and with sclerotized rim (mainland species), in
G. murphyi
also with cluster of sexually dimorphic hairs ( Fig. 27C ). Sternum slightly wider than long, with pair of indistinct anterior humps near coxae 1 ( Fig. 13D ; ~5–20 µm high, 20 µm diameter at basis). Abdomen globular. Gonopore either with four epiandrous spigots arranged in two pairs (
G. baerti
,
G. bella
,
G. gabito
; Figs 6F , 13E ; see also Huber 2000 : fig. 127) or without epiandrous spigots (
G. spiniphila
,
G. murphyi
; Figs 20E , 28E, F ). ALS with one strongly widened spigot, one long pointed spigot, and five cylindrical spigots, of which one is much wider than the others ( Figs 6C , 22A, B , 28A ); PMS with two conical spigots ( Figs 6C , 22A , 28A ); PLS without spigots.

subSubSection.paragraph: CHELICERAE. Chelicerae main segment unmodified ( Fig. 3 ); with stridulatory files consisting of ~30–50 ridges, distances between ridges either constant throughout (1.5–1.6 µm) or wider proximally (2.0 µm) than distally (1.1 µm), either with or without further fine subdivision ( Figs 8B , 13A , 20C , 27F ). Fang with curved proximal process ( Figs 8A , 13C , 27E ).

PALPS. Palpal coxa unmodified. Trochanter without process or with very short ventral protrusion. Femur proximally with prolateral stridulatory pick (modified hair; Figs 8C , 20D ), distally slightly widened but without modification. Femur-patella joints variably shifted towards prolateral side. Tibia oval, with two trichobothria. Tibia-tarsus joints slightly shifted towards retrolateral side. Palpal tarsal organ weakly to strongly raised ( Figs 9A–C , 14E , 23D , 29E ; see also Huber 2000 : fig. 77), diameter 4.1–6.7 µm, diameter of opening 1.0–1.7 µm. Procursus retrolateral distal process simple ( Figs 7B , 14B , 21B ) or bifid ( Fig. 25B , 29C ); dorsal process curved towards prolateral; tip of dorsal process covered by large flap of genital bulb or lodged in pocket of genital bulb ( Figs 7B , 14B , 21B ). Genital bulb with distal apophysis ( Figs 7B , 17B, C , 25B, C ), in
G. spiniphila
also with retrolateral-dorsal process and pair of ventral processes ( Figs 17 , 21C, D ); in
G. gabito
and
G. murphyi
with small prolateral distal apophysis (arrows in Figs 12B , 25A ; 29D ); sperm duct opening on prolateral-ventral side directly on bulb ( Figs 7H , 21D , 29D ).

caption.paragraph:
FIG. 4. Known distribution of
Galapa Huber, 2000
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female

In general, similar to males but sternum without pair of anterior humps, chelicerae without stridulatory files ( Figs 8D , 13B , 27G ), cheliceral fangs unmodified, clypeus never strongly protruding ( Fig. 27D ) and without sclerotized rim, and palpal tarsal organ less strongly raised ( Figs 14F , 29F ; see also fig. 76 in Huber 2000 ) and slightly smaller (diameter 4.0–4.3 µm, diameter of opening 1.0–1.2 µm). Legs slightly shorter than in males (male / female tibia 1 length: ~1.0–1.2); tibia 1 length 0.37 – 0.74. Spinnerets as in male ( Figs 6B , 13F , 22C, D , 28C ). Epigynum with simple semicircular anterior plate, weakly protruding, posteriorly straight or indented medially ( Figs 6E , 20F , 28D ); posterior plate short and simple, with or without indistinct median division. Internal genitalia ( Figs 11 , 16 , 24 , 32 ) very simple, apparently without pore plates; with large membranous structure (with or without median membranous process), either directed towards posterior and covered by posterior epigynal plate or directed towards anterior and covered by anterior epigynal plate.

Relationships . Molecular (UCE) data (G. Meng, L. Podsiadlowski, B.A. Huber, unpubl. data) suggest that the closest known relative of
Galapa
is an undescribed species from Brazil , Piauí , Parque Nacional da Serra da Capivara. That species is known from a single male specimen that does not share any of the diagnostic genital characters of
Galapa
listed above. Together, these two clades are sister to
Kambiwa
+
Pemona
, two further South American genera. All of these together are sister of the southern South American genus
Guaranita
. Thus,
Galapa
is deeply nested within South American Ninetinae .

Even though a NJ tree ( Fig. 1 ) is not supposed to reliably reflect phylogeny, it shows two splits worth mentioning. First, within
Galapa
,
G. bella
( Galapagos ) is sister to the mainland species. Several morphological characters support this split: (1) Mainland species share a proximal ridge on the basis of the leg trichobothria; in
G. bella
, these bases are round, which is likely the plesiomorphic condition; (2) in mainland species, the male palpal tarsal organ has moved to the procursus, while in
G. bella
it has the plesiomorphic position on the tarsus; (3) in mainland species, the female internal genitalia are directed towards posterior, while in
G. bella
they are directed towards anterior, which is probably the plesiomorphic condition; (4) finally, body size and leg length are smaller in mainland species than in species from Galapagos (carapace width: ~0.4 vs. ~0.5; tibia 1 length:>0.60 versus <0.55); the plesiomorphic condition is unknown.

Second, the Central American (Costa Rican)
G. murphyi
is nested within a group of mainland South American species. This position is supported by the loss of epiandrous spigots in
G. murphyi
and
G. spiniphila
, while
G. bella
and
G. gabito
share the plesiomorphic presence of four epiandrous spigots.

Distribution . The genus is known from Galápagos, northern Colombia , northeastern Venezuela , and Costa Rica ( Fig. 4 ). The distribution map of these tiny and poorly collected spiders suggests a wide range, but the ecological conditions (semi-arid, exposed habitats; see below) are not common in this region, so the suitable habitats may actually be quite limited. This is supported by our biogeographic analysis (see below).

Natural history . Representatives of the genus
Galapa
appear restricted to semi-arid and sun-exposed habitats where they occupy the leaf litter, spaces under stones, and dead cacti and dry branches lying on the ground and hollowed by termites ( Fig. 5 ). We never found them in neighboring, more forested, shaded, and humid sites. When disturbed, they ran rapidly. In glass vials, both males and females built small webs on which they were seen resting a few hours after being captured ( Fig. 2D ). Egg-sacs are flat (a single layer of eggs) and contain up to six eggs that are wrapped by a few barely visible silk lines; egg diameters range from 0.38 to 0.43 mm . For further information, see individual natural history sections below.
Composition . The genus now includes six nominal species: three on the Galápagos, one in Costa Rica (with a dubious record in Colombia ), and two in northern South America.

Male gonopore and epiandrous spigots. Abbreviations: aep, anterior (main) epigynal plate; ALS, anterior lateral spinneret; pep, posterior epigynal plate; PMS, posterior median spinneret. Scale bars: 100 µm (A, E), 10 µm (B–D, F).

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription (amendments of Huber 2000 , based on specimens reported in Huber & Acurio 2022 )

Male carapace width 0.47–0.53. Distance PME-PME 45 µm; diameter PME 45 µm; distance PME-ALE 15 µm; distance AME-AME 15 µm; diameter AME 30 µm. Tibia 1 in four males (including holotype ): 0.66, 0.67, 0.68, 0.74; diameters of leg femora 0.10, of leg tibiae: 0.06. Clypeus not more protruding than in female, without sclerotized rim. Sternum with pair of barely visible anterior humps near coxae 1 (~5 µm high, 20 µm diameter at basis). Gonopore with four epiandrous spigots arranged in two pairs ( Fig. 6F ). ALS with one strongly widened spigot, one long pointed spigot, and five cylindrical spigots, of which one is much wider than the others ( Fig. 6C ); PMS with two conical spigots ( Fig. 6C ); PLS without spigots. Chelicerae in general very similar to congeners (cf. Huber 2000 : fig. 384), with curved process proximally on fang ( Fig. 8A ); with stridulatory files consisting of ~50 ridges, distances between ridges 1.5–1.6 µm throughout, without further fine subdivision ( Fig. 8B ). Palpal femur proximally with prolateral stridulatory pick ( Fig. 8C ); femur-patella joints strongly shifted towards prolateral side; tibia oval, with two trichobothria; tibia-tarsus joints barely shifted towards retrolateral side; palpal tarsal organ strongly raised ( Fig. 9A–C ), diameter 6.7 µm, diameter of opening 1.7 µm; procursus with pointed retrolateral-distal process directed towards proximal and dorsal ( Fig. 7B ); tip of dorsal process covered by dorsal flap of genital bulb ( Fig. 7B ) but not lodged in pocket as in South American congeners; genital bulb with large distal apophysis ( Fig. 7B ), apparently without retrolateral-dorsal process and ventral processes; sperm duct opening on prolateral-ventral side directly on bulb ( Fig. 7H ). Legs with round cuticular plates ( Fig. 10A, B ; diameter 4–5 µm) and rimmed pores ( Fig. 10A–C ; outer diameter 3.4–3.7 µm, diameter of opening 0.2 µm) apparently on all leg segments. Sexually dimorphic short vertical hairs present on tibiae 1 and 2 ( Fig. 8E–H ), length ~15 µm, diameter at basis 1.2 µm. Chemoreceptive hairs similar in size (length ~13 µm, diameter at basis 1.7 µm) but with side branch ( Fig. 10F ). Retrolateral trichobothrium of tibia 1 at 60%; prolateral trichobothrium absent on tibia 1. Leg tarsal organs capsulate ( Fig. 9E, F ; diameter 3.7–4.5 µm, diameter of opening 1.0–1.4 µm). Main tarsal claws with ~10–11 tines ( Fig. 10F, G )
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female in general similar to male but sternum without anterior humps, chelicerae without stridulatory files ( Fig. 8D ), cheliceral fangs unmodified. Tibia 1 in two females : 0.65, 0.68 ( Huber 2000 ). The female from Santa Cruz, near Canal de Itabaca, has longer legs (tibia 1: 0.78) and a CO1 distance to specimens from 1 km SW of Garrapatero beach of 8.8–9.0%. It may in fact represent a different species. Spinnerets as in male ( Fig. 6B, D ). Epigynum ( Figs 6E , 11A, B ) with simple semicircular anterior plate, weakly protruding, posteriorly not indented medially; posterior plate short and simple, without median division. Internal genitalia ( Fig. 11C, D ) very simple, apparently without pore plates; membranous bilobed structure with short median process, covered by anterior epigynal plate (not by posterior epigynal plate as in South American congeners).

caption.paragraph:

Galapa bella ( Gertsch & Peck, 1992 )
from Santa Cruz, SW of Garrapatero beach. A. Right male palpal tarsus, dorsal view, showing position of tarsal organ (arrow). B, C. Male palpal tarsal organ. D–F. Tarsal organs on female tarsus 2, male tarsus 4, and male tarsus 1. Scale bars: 10 µm (A, B), 2 µm (C–F).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution . Known from several localities on Santa Cruz Island, Galápagos . The single female reported from Santa Cruz, Islote Venecia (~ 0.5178°S , 90.4760°W ), by Gertsch & Peck (1992) , may also represent this species rather than
G. baerti
. The species has been claimed to be present on Genovesa and Pinta Islands (
Baert et al. 2008
; Baert 2013 , 2014 ) but without specimen and collection data, so these records are here considered dubious.

caption.paragraph:

from Santa Cruz, SW of Garrapatero beach. A, B. Rimmed pores and cuticular plates on male tibia 4 and on female tibia 2. C. Rimmed pore on male metatarsus 2. D. Base of trichobothrium on left male metatarsus 1. E. Right male metatarsus-tarsus joint, retrolateral-dorsal view. F, G. Tips of right male tarsi 3 and 4, retrolateral views (arrows: putative chemoreceptors). Scale bars: 2 µm (A, B), 1 µm (C), 10 µm (D–G).

FIG. 11.
Galapa bella ( Gertsch & Peck, 1992 )
females from Santa Cruz, SW of Garrapatero beach; ZFMK Gal55. A, B. Abdomens, ventral views. C, D. Cleared internal genitalia, dorsal views. Scale bars: 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Natural history . At the type locality (Charles Darwin Research Station), the species seems to have been replaced by the introduced
Modisimus culicinus (Simon, 1893) ( Huber & Acurio 2022 )
. The specimens newly collected in 2019 (listed in Huber & Acurio 2022 ) were found in very dry and exposed habitats near the sea, under rocks and small stones and pebbles ( Fig. 5A, B ). At both localities (near Garrapatero beach and near Canal de Itabaca), the spiders occupied the drier upper layer of stones, while
Anopsicus banksi (Gertsch, 1939)
was found in the deeper, slightly more humid layers. The spiders ran very quickly when disturbed.
Figs 2E, F , 12–16

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology . The species name honors the Colombian novelist Gabriel García Márquez (1927–2014), considered one of the most significant authors of the 20 th century and known affectionately as Gabo or Gabito in Latin America. The epithet is used as a noun in apposition.

Description .

MEASUREMENTS. Total body length 0.96, carapace width 0.38. Distance PME-PME 35 µm; diameter PME 30 µm; distance PME-ALE 15 µm; distance AME-AME 10 µm; diameter AME 20 µm. Leg 1: 1.68 (0.46 + 0.12 + 0.44 + 0.38+ 0.28), tibia 2: 0.34, tibia 3: 0.30, tibia 4: 0.48; tibia 1 L/d: 9; diameters of leg femora 0.075, of leg tibiae: 0.050.
COLOUR (in ethanol). Prosoma and legs pale ochre-yellow, carapace without pattern, legs without darker rings; abdomen ochre-grey with indistinct internal marks.

BODY. Habitus as in Fig. 2E . Ocular area not raised. Carapace without thoracic groove. Clypeus slightly more protruding than in female, with sclerotized rim. Sternum slightly wider than long (0.26/0.23), with pair of small anterior processes near coxae 1 ( Fig. 13D ; 20 µm long, 20 µm diameter at basis). Abdomen globular. Gonopore with four epiandrous spigots ( Fig. 13E ). Spinnerets apparently as in female (see below; dirty in scanned male).

Right male cheliceral fang with process (arrow), distal view. D. Male sternal hump. E. Male gonopore with epiandrous spigots. F. Female ALS. Scale bars: 10 µm (A, C–F), 20 µm (B).

subSubSection.paragraph: PALPS. As in Figs 12 , 14A–D ; coxa unmodified; trochanter without process; femur proximally with prolateral stridulatory pick, distally slightly widened but without modification; femur-patella joints slightly shifted towards prolateral side; tibia oval, with two trichobothria; tibia-tarsus joints slightly shifted towards retrolateral side; palpal tarsal organ strongly raised ( Fig. 14E ), diameter 5.5 µm, diameter of opening 1.3 µm; procursus with pointed retrolateral-distal process distinctively directed towards dorsal and with dorsal process curved towards prolateral and lodged in pocket of genital bulb ( Fig. 14B ); genital bulb with small distal apophysis and similar prolateral distal apophysis; sperm duct opening apparently on prolateral-ventral side directly on bulb.

Abbreviations: b, genital bulb; da, distal apophysis of genital bulb; dp, dorsal process of procursus; pr, procursus; rp, retrolateral-distal process of procursus; ta, tarsus; to, tarsal organ. Scale bars: 100 µm (A–D), 2 µm (E, F).

subSubSection.paragraph: LEGS. Without spines and curved hairs. With round cuticular plates ( Fig. 15D ; diameter 4–5 µm) and rimmed pores ( Fig. 15E ; outer diameter 3 µm, diameter of opening 0.3 µm) apparently on all leg segments. Sexually dimorphic short vertical hairs present on tibiae 1 and 2 ( Fig. 15A, B ), barely visible in dissecting microscope, length ~15 µm, diameter at basis 1.0 µm. Chemoreceptive hairs similar in size (length ~10 µm, diameter at basis 1.3 µm) but with side branch (cf. Fig. 15F ). Retrolateral trichobothrium of tibia 1 at 57%; prolateral trichobothrium absent on tibia 1. Tarsus 1 with five pseudosegments, fairly distinct; leg tarsal organs capsulate. Main tarsal claws with ~9–11 tines.
Variation (male)
Tibia 1 in eight males (including holotype ): 0.41–0.44 (mean 0.43).

subSubSection.paragraph: Female

Natural history . Most specimens were beaten out of dead cacti lying on the ground in a dry forest covering hills near the sea ( Fig. 5C ). They shared this microhabitat with another species of Ninetinae , an undescribed representative of
Ibotyporanga
.
Distribution . Known from type locality only, in Magdalena , Colombia ( Fig. 4 ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Figs 2G–I , 3B , 17–24

Galapa spiniphila Huber
in Huber & Villarreal 2020: 58 , figs 174–175, 178–188 ( ♂ ♀ ). Diagnosis (amended; see Huber & Villarreal 2020 ). Males are distinguished from known congeners by presence of four distal apophyses on genital bulb ( Figs 17 , 21C, D ; pair of ventral apophyses, distal apophysis, and retrolateral-dorsal apophysis) and by simple (not bifid) retrolateral process on procursus directed towards retrolateral (rather than towards dorsal). Females without sclerite in ventral wall of uterus externus (as opposed to
G. gabito
) but externally possibly indistinguishable from
G. murphyi
; large membranous structure in internal genitalia not bilobed as in
G. gabito
and
G. murphyi
, with distinctive median membranous process (arrows in Fig. 24E, G, I ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks . The Colombian specimens below are assigned tentatively to this species because there are some minor but apparently consistent morphological differences among them and between Colombian and Venezuelan specimens (see Variation below and Figs 17–19 ). They are not described as separate species mainly because of the low CO1 distances among the sequenced Colombian specimens (3.3–4.8%). The distances between the Colombian specimens on one side and the topotypical Venezuelan
G. spiniphila
specimen on the other side are higher (9.4–10.1%), but the morphological differences between them are of the same degree as those among Colombian specimens. We thus describe the new Colombian specimens as morphs within
G. spiniphila
, pending further analysis. The topotypical morph is here named ‘Paraguaná morph’.
The specimens from Magdalena are extremely bleached and difficult to study.They seem to share the morphology of the Pueblo Bello morph.

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription .

MEASUREMENTS. Total body length 0.98, carapace width 0.43. Distance PME-PME 35 µm; diameter PME 35 µm; distance PME-ALE 10 µm; Distance AME-AME 10 µm; diameter AME 15 µm. COLOUR (in ethanol). Prosoma and legs pale ochre-yellow, carapace without pattern, legs without darker rings; abdomen monochromous ochre-grey.

subSubSection.paragraph: LEGS. Without spines and curved hairs. With round cuticular plates (cf. Fig. 23F ; diameter 6–7 µm) and rimmed pores (cf. Fig. 23G ; outer diameter 3.5 µm, diameter of opening 0.3 µm) apparently on all leg segments. Sexually dimorphic short vertical hairs present on tibiae 1 and 2 ( Fig. 23A, B ), barely visible in dissecting microscope, length ~17 µm, diameter at basis 1.1 µm. Chemoreceptive hairs similar in size (length ~12 µm, diameter at basis 1.5 µm) but with side branch ( Fig. 22E, F ). Retrolateral trichobothrium of tibia 1 at 64%; prolateral trichobothrium absent on tibia 1. Tarsus 1 with five pseudosegments, fairly distinct; leg tarsal organs capsulate (cf. Fig. 23E ; diameter 3.7 µm, diameter of opening 0.7 µm). Main tarsal claws with ~10–11 tines ( Fig. 22F ).
Female (near Papayal)

In general, similar to male ( Fig. 2H ) but sternum without pair of anterior humps, chelicerae apparently without stridulatory files, cheliceral fangs unmodified, clypeus less protruding and without sclerotized rim. Tibia 1 in five females : 0.40 – 0.44 (mean 0.42). Spinnerets as in male ( Fig. 22C, D ). Epigynum ( Figs 20F , 24A ) with simple semicircular anterior plate, weakly protruding, posteriorly indented medially; posterior plate short and simple, with indistinct median division. Internal genitalia ( Fig. 24D, E ) very simple, apparently without pore plates; membranous structure with long median process (twisted in Fig. 24D, E ), covered by posterior epigynal plate.

Females of the four morphs are apparently indistinguishable. The posterior margin of the anterior epigynal plate is straight in the Pueblo Bello morph ( Fig. 24C ) but undulating in the other morphs ( Fig. 24A, B ; cf. Huber & Villarreal 2020 : figs 183, 186); however, this seems to vary within populations and is also slightly dependent on the angle of view and on the degree of opening of the epigynal cleft. The median posterior process in the internal genitalia appears variably long (e.g. longer in the Paraguaná morph than in the Pueblo Bello morph) but this observation rests on a very small sample of cleared specimens and may partly be an artifact (e.g., the process appears short in the Papayal morph but apparently only because it is twisted).
Tibia 1 lengths among the four morphs are widely overlapping and thus pooled here. Tibia 1 in 17 males : 0.47–0.54 (mean 0.50); in 29 females : 0.40–0.50 (mean 0.44).

Natural history . At Riohacha, all specimens were beaten out of dead cactus branches lying on the ground in a degraded roadside environment with bushes and a few small trees. At Papayal, most specimens were also beaten out of dead cacti lying on the ground in a similar roadside environment ( Fig. 5D ). At Pueblo Bello, the spiders were found in a low, dry forest on a roadside hill. They were beaten from old dry branches lying on the ground and hollowed by termites. At all three localities, they shared the used microhabitats with another species of Ninetinae , an undescribed representative of
Ibotyporanga
; at Riohacha, also with
Modisimus culicinus (Simon, 1893)
. Two egg-sacs contained six eggs each, with an egg diameter of 0.38–0.40.
Distribution . This species seems to be widespread in north-western Venezuela and northern Colombia ( Fig. 4 ).
Figs 2A–D , 3A , 25–32

Diagnosis . Males are easily distinguished from known congeners by bifid retrolateral process on procursus ( Figs 25B , 29C ); also by slightly spiraling distal bulbal apophysis ( Fig. 25 ). Females are barely distinguishable from known congeners; posterior epigynal plate medially not divided (South American species with indistinct median division); main epigynal plate shorter than in species from Galapagos and posteriorly not indented medially (as opposed to most
G. spiniphila
morphs); internal genitalia with bilobed or rectangular membranous structure ( Fig. 32D–I ; similar to
G. gabito
), without median membranous process (as opposed to
G. spiniphila
); without internal sclerite as in
G. gabito
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology . The species name honors the British arachnologist John Murphy (1922–2021), who first discovered this species.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remark . The labels accompanying the specimens of J. Murphy do not specify the locality beyond “ Guanacaste ”. However,
Platnick et al. (2012)
published on goblin spiders collected by J. Murphy on the same day, and with the same ecological (“forest leaf litter”) and altitude data ( 90 m ), giving Cañas as locality. We thus assume that the specimens were collected in or near Cañas.
Description .

MEASUREMENTS.Total body length 1.12, carapace width 0.42. Distance PME-PME 40 µm; diameter PME 40 µm; distance PME-ALE 20 µm; distance AME-AME 10 µm; diameter AME 25 µm. Leg 1: 1.94 (0.52 + 0.14 + 0.50 + 0.46+ 0.32), tibia 2: 0.40, tibia 3: 0.34, tibia 4: 0.56; tibia 1 L/d: 9; diameters of leg femora 0.090, of leg tibiae: 0.055.
COLOUR (in ethanol). Prosoma and legs ochre-yellow, carapace without pattern, legs without darker rings; abdomen ochre-grey with indistinct internal marks.

subSubSection.paragraph: CHELICERAE. As in Fig. 3A ; with stridulatory files consisting of ~32 ridges, distances between ridges 1.5 µm throughout ( Fig. 27F ); fang with proximal rounded process ( Fig. 27E ).

PALPS. As in Figs 25 , 29A–D ; coxa unmodified; trochanter without process; femur proximally with prolateral stridulatory pick, distally slightly widened but without modification; femur-patella joints slightly shifted towards prolateral side; tibia oval, with two trichobothria; tibia-tarsus joints slightly shifted towards retrolateral side; palpal tarsal organ strongly raised ( Fig. 29E ), diameter 5 µm, diameter of opening 1.2 µm; procursus with distinctive bifid retrolateral-distal process and with dorsal process curved towards prolateral and lodged in pocket of genital bulb; genital bulb with slightly spiraling distal apophysis ( Fig. 25 ) and small prolateral apophysis subdistally (arrow in Figs 25A , 29D ); sperm duct opening on prolateral-ventral side directly on bulb ( Fig. 29D ).

caption.paragraph:
FIG. 32.
Galapa murphyi Huber
sp. n. ; female abdomens, ventral views, and cleared female genitalia, ventral and dorsal views. A, B, D–G. Two specimens from Costa Rica, near Playa Iguanita, ZFMK Ar 24224. C, H, I. From 2 km NW of Cañas, ZFMK Ar 24226. Scale bars: 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: LEGS. Without spines and curved hairs. With round cuticular plates ( Figs 30E , 31F ; diameter 4–5 µm) and rimmed pores ( Fig. 31F ; outer diameter 3 µm, diameter of opening 0.4 µm) apparently on all leg segments. Sexually dimorphic short vertical hairs present on tibia 1 ( Fig. 30A ), barely visible in dissecting microscope, length 17 µm, diameter at basis 1.2 µm. Chemoreceptive hairs similar in size (length 14 µm, diameter at basis 1.4 µm) but with side branch ( Fig. 30F, G ). Retrolateral trichobothrium of tibia 1 at 60%; prolateral trichobothrium absent on tibia 1. Tarsus 1 with five pseudosegments, poorly visible in dissecting microscope; leg tarsal organs capsulate ( Fig. 31A–D ), outer diameter 2–3 µm, diameter of opening 0.8–1.0 µm. Main tarsal claws with 9–11 tines ( Fig. 30F ); claws of tarsus 4 different from others (tines more directed towards distal; cf. Fig. 30H ).
Variation (male)

Tibia 1 in 20 other males from Guanacaste (except northern Guanacaste): 0.45–0.54 (mean 0.49). The male from northern Guanacaste ( 6 km S of La Cruz) differs slightly in the position and shape of the bifid retrolateral-distal process on the procursus ( Fig 26 —more proximal position on procursus; directed more towards lateral than towards proximal). In addition, the distal bulbal apophysis is slightly thinner, and the CO1 distances between a specimen from this locality and three other sequenced specimens were relatively high, at 9.4–10.1%. This male (and the accompanying specimens from this locality) are thus assigned tentatively to this species; tibia 1: 0.54. The three males from Colombia are in very bad condition (bleached) and thus difficult to compare; their palps are slightly smaller, but the bifid retrolateral-distal process on the procursus seems to be as in the holotype ; tibia 1: 0.48, 0.48, 0.54.
Female

In general, similar to male ( Fig. 2B–D ) but sternum without pair of anterior humps, chelicerae without stridulatory files ( Fig. 27G ), cheliceral fangs unmodified, clypeus less protruding ( Fig. 27D ) and without sclerotized rim, carapace with shorter hairs, and palpal tarsal organ less raised ( Fig. 29F ) and slightly smaller (diameter 4 µm, diameter of opening 1.2 µm). Tibia 1 in 19 females from Guanacaste (except northern Guanacaste): 0.39 – 0.48 (mean 0.44); in female from northern Guanacaste: 0.49; in females from Colombia : 0.42, 0.44. Epigynum ( Figs 28D , 32A– C ) with simple semicircular anterior plate, weakly protruding, posteriorly not indented medially; posterior plate short and simple, undivided medially. Internal genitalia ( Fig. 32D–I ) very simple, apparently without pore plates; with rectangular or bilobed membranous structure (without median process), covered by posterior epigynal plate.

Natural history . The spiders were found under rocks and in dry leaf litter in exposed habitats, in open spaces of dry forests and on roadsides ( Fig. 5E, F ). No specimens were found in neighboring, more forested and humid sites. Two egg-sacs contained four and five eggs , respectively; egg diameters: 0.41–0.43. In glass vials, both males and females built small webs on which they were seen resting a few hours after being captured ( Fig. 2D ).

Distribution . Known from several localities in Guanacaste , Costa Rica ( Fig. 4 ). Specimens from northern Guanacaste are assigned tentatively, either because the only available male differs slightly (see Variation above) and CO1 distances to other sequenced specimens are relatively high (9.4–10.1%), or because no adult specimens are available. Specimens from Colombia are assigned tentatively because they are in very bad condition and cannot be properly compared.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remark . The CO1 sequence of a female from Venezuela , Falcón , SE of Bariro, suggests that it represents a further species ( Fig. 1 ). The sequence is more similar to sequences of

(13.5–14.5%, mean 13.9%, N=4) than to sequences of
G. spiniphila
(16.0–18.8%, mean 17.5%, N=4) and
G. gabito
(18.2%, N=1). We do not formally describe this species because no males are available. Tibia 1 length: 0.47 (missing in second female). Epigynum and cleared female genitalia as in Fig. 33 , with distinctively rounded membranous internal structure.

subSection.paragraph:
The principal component analysis (PCA) of the predictor layers used in the distribution modeling showed that only five axes explained more of the variance than expected by chance, i.e., more than 4.54% of the proportion of variance (Supplementary File, Table S3). These five axes explained 87.9% of the variance.The distribution modelling analysis attributed a higher importance to the second PC axis, which represented 72.6% of the contribution (Supplementary File, Table S4). This axis was most positively correlated with the precipitation of the wettest month and the mean temperature of the driest quarter, but negatively correlated with the mean diurnal range and precipitation seasonality (Supplementary File, Table S5). Areas with high relative occurrence rate (ROR) for
Galapa
were observed in several countries, showing a discontinuous pattern. Some of these areas (numbers 1–6 in Fig. 34A ) have no record of
Galapa
representatives. Other pholcids shared this sampling bias (see Discussion).

The altitude (d.f. = 7, resid. dev. = 968692, p = 0.000) and the aridity index (d.f. = 7, resid. dev. = 6623908, p = 0.000) were significantly different among the points of occurrences of Pholcidae taxa. Ninetines (including
Galapa
) and artemines (i.e., the Venezuelan
Chisosa caquetio Huber, 2019
) are known from significantly lower sites than those recorded for Pholcinae (mainly
Metagonia Simon, 1893
; Fig. 36A ). All these taxa together occur on average at significantly lower sites than representatives of Modisiminae ( Fig. 36A ). The aridity index, used herein as a surrogate for environmental conditions, was significantly lower for
Galapa
populations from Galapagos, Venezuela , Colombia , other Ninetinae , and Arteminae, than for other pholcids ( Fig. 36B ). The
Galapa
populations from Costa Rica , however, occur in regions with a similar aridity index as for Modisiminae and Pholcinae, i.e., in relatively more humid conditions ( Fig. 36B ).

The disjunct distribution of
Galapa
is uncommon among Neotropical pholcids. Disregarding artifacts of wrong generic assignments (e.g., in
Coryssocnemis Simon, 1893
; probably also in
Psilochorus Simon, 1893
; cf. Huber 2000 : Appendix 3), only
Ibotyporanga Mello-Leitão, 1944
( Ninetinae ) and
Micropholcus Deeleman-Reinhold & Prinsen, 1987
(Pholcinae) have wide and disjunct distributions in the Neotropical region ( Huber & Brescovit 2003 ;
Huber et al. 2014
; Huber & Villarreal 2020 ). Whether such distribution patterns are real or an artificial consequence of sampling bias remains to be established and will require focused sampling. In the present study, the distribution modelling suggested six geographic regions with high environmental suitability for representatives of
Galapa
( Figs 34 , 35 ) that should be prioritized for further sampling. These areas are situated in the coastal regions of Central America and in coastal and continental areas in northern South America ( Fig. 34A ).Additionally, it will be important for future campaigns to include Ninetinae as a priority-target. Previous studies have shown that the probability of collecting these spiders as a byproduct of general sampling tends to be low (
Huber et al. 2023a
).

Numbered sites represent areas with higher ROR (except for the Galapagos archipelago, detailed in B), namely: (1) Pacific biogeographic region in Nicaragua; (2) Gulf of Panama; (3) Gulf of Venezuela; (4) Apure-Villavicencio dry forests and Llanos ecoregions; (5) Guianan savanna ecoregion; and (6) Tumbes-Piura and Ecuadorian dry forests ecoregions. Letters a–c indicate statistically significant groups (p = 0.000), based on contrast analyses. Note that the altitudinal range is significantly lower for Ninetinae and Arteminae, compared to other Pholcidae . subSection.paragraph:
In Nicaragua , whose Pholcidae fauna is poorly known (currently only six species; see Huber 1996 , 1998 , 2000 ), a high suitability area occurs in the Pacific Lowlands province (sensu Morrone 2017 ). In Panama , high suitability areas occur in coastal areas around the Gulf of Panama , far from the better sampled sites close to Panama City ( Fig. 35A ). In Venezuela , two discontinuous high suitability areas occur ( Fig. 35B ): (1) around the Gulf of Venezuela , a region that encompasses the Guajira-Barranquilla xeric scrubs, Paraguaná xeric scrubs and Lara- Falcón dry forests ecoregions; and (2) the Apure-Villavicencio dry forests and Llanos ecoregions (sensu
Olson et al. 2001
). By contrast, better sampled Venezuelan ecoregions (e.g., Maracaibo dry forests, Venezuelan Andes montane forests, La Costa xeric shrublands, and Cordillera La Costa montane forests) do not present any
Galapa
records or high environmental suitability. On the border between Peru and Ecuador , high suitability areas occur in the TumbesPiura and the Ecuadorian dry forests ecoregions ( Fig. 34A ). Finally, on the border between Brazil and Guiana , a high suitability area occurs in the Guianan savanna ecoregion ( Fig. 34A ).

In the Galapagos archipelago, most lowland areas had a high relative occurrence rate (ROR; i.e., high environmental suitability for
Galapa
), while higher elevation areas presented a low ROR ( Fig. 34B ). In line with this result, extensive sampling of high altitude areas has not revealed any representative of
Galapa
( Baert 2013 , 2014 ; Huber & Acurio 2022 ). This is also consistent with our comparative analysis showing that representatives of
Galapa
live in low altitudinal regions ( Fig. 36A ). In this respect,
Galapa
is similar to other ninetines from Central America and northern South America, while some southern South American and North American ninetines occur at much higher altitudes (
Huber et al. 2023 a
, 2023b).

In the Caribbean Sea, several islands had a high ROR (e.g., Netherlands Antilles , Isla de Tortuga , and Isla de Margarita), while the eastern islands in the Lesser Antilles (i.e., Trinidad & Tobago , Grenada , etc.) had a low suitability ( Figs 34A , 35B ; see also Supplementary File, Fig. S7 ). Among the high ROR islands, Curaçao is of particular interest. It has been sampled intensively with a focus on Ninetinae (by BAH), which resulted in a high number of records and specimens of the Ninetinae genus
Papiamenta Huber, 2000
, while no representatives of
Galapa
were found ( Fig. 35B ). Therefore, the absence of
Galapa
in Curaçao is unlikely to result from sampling bias. This case supports the idea that current distribution patterns result from a combination of factors. Areas with high environmental suitability for
Galapa
might reflect the niche conservatism postulated for ninetines in general and present a typical environmental niche suitable for these spiders (cf.
Huber et al. 2023a
), while limited dispersal abilities and geographic barriers result in highly suitable and geographically neighboring yet unoccupied areas.

Disregarding sampling biases, niche conservatism, and limited dispersal abilities, the current distribution of
Galapa
might also represent a relict distribution or the effect of competitive exclusion. Ninetinae represents an old lineage that may have emerged as early as the mid-Jurassic (
Dimitrov et al. 2013
), when most of what is now South America, Africa, and southern North America was covered by dry environments ( Sellwood & Valdes 2008 ). It is thus reasonable to speculate that ninetines had a wide distribution in the past, owing to their association with dry environments ( Fig. 36B ) and their niche conservatism (
Huber et al. 2023a
). Through the Cretaceous and the Cenozoic, the environment shifted significantly throughout the Neotropical region, with the expansion of rainforests decreasing the availability of arid or semi-arid lands ( Morley 2011 ). Meanwhile, Pholcinae and Modisiminae (besides many other taxa with similar ecological requirements) occupied and thrived in the mesic environments, being the most diversified pholcids in the Neotropics ( Huber 2011 ). Competitive exclusion among pholcids has been reported for
Galapa bella
, whose abundance appears negatively correlated with the abundance of
Modisimus culicinus (Simon, 1893)
, an introduced species in the Galapagos Islands ( Huber & Acurio 2022 ).

Table S1 . Geographic origins and GenBank accession numbers of the complete set of taxa used for the NJ tree, sorted as in Fig. S1 .

Table S2 . CO1 Kimura 2-parameter (K2P) genetic distances among sequenced specimens, calculated from the untrimmed alignment using MEGA 11. Pairwise deletion strategy was used to deal with gaps/missing data in the alignment. Taxa are sorted as in Fig. S1 .

Table S3. Significant principal components (PC) for the environmental layers used as predictors for the species distribution modelling (SDM) for
Galapa
representatives. The used PCs (1-5) are those in which the proportion of variance is higher than expected by chance (i.e., for 22 variables, those that explain at least 4.54%).

Table S4. Contribution of the principal components described in Table S5 to the species distribution modelling, carried out with Maxent, without applying a threshold rule, with 500 maximum interactions, random test percentage of 25%, raw output formatted, with 15 bootstrap replicates, and by choosing to remove duplicates from the same gridcell. The average training AUC for the replicate runs is 0.971, and the standard deviation is 0.004.

Table S5. Pearson correlation coefficients between the principal components (PC) and the environmental layers used as predictors for the species distribution modelling (SDM) for Galapa representatives. The used PCs (1-5) are those in which the proportion of variance is higher than expected by chance (i.e., for 22 variables, those that explain at least 4.54%). Variables are sorted in order of importance for the second principal component, as it was the most important variable for the distribution modelling (see Table S4).

Table S6. Significant principal components (PC) for the ordination of the points of occurrences of pholcids in the study area, based on the environmental predictors. The significant PCs (1-6) are those in which the proportion of variance is higher than expected by chance (i.e., for 22 variables, those that explain at least 4.54%).

Table S7. Eigenvectors of covariance factor of the principal components (PC) for the ordination of the points of occurrences of pholcids in the study area, based on the environmental predictors. The significant PCs (1-6) are those in which the proportion of variance is higher than expected by chance (i.e., for 22 variables, those that explain at least 4.54%). Variables are sorted in order of importance for the first principal component.
